productText:
000
FXUS62 KTAE 201904
AFDTAE

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Tallahassee FL
304 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

...New NEAR TERM, SHORT TERM, LONG TERM, MARINE, FIRE WEATHER, HYDROLOGY...

.NEAR TERM...
(Through Wednesday)
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Dry air across the area continues filtering in on northerly flow
this afternoon behind a now stalled front over the northern Gulf
and the Florida Peninsula. This will lead to a calm, quiet night
across the forecast area with lows in the upper 60s and lower 70s.
However, some patchy fog cannot be ruled out near the I-75
corridor. A little bit of moisture returns on the easterly or 
northeasterly flow on Wednesday, which will lead to some showers 
and storms near the I-75 corridor and Suwannee Valley, but rain 
chances are generally 40 percent or less. Highs will be in the 
lower to middle 90s, but the lower dew points will constrain the 
heat index values to 100 or less.

&&

.SHORT TERM...
(Wednesday night through Thursday night)
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

A shortwave will round the base of the trough over the eastern US
Wednesday night into Thursday. PWATs will also increase to 1.6 to
1.8 inches. This shortwave along with increasing moisture will 
lead to high rain chances, mainly over the southern and eastern 
parts of the area Thursday afternoon. There is some possibility of
strong storms Thursday given about 15 to 20 kt of deep layer 
shear and ample DCAPE with mid-level dry air lingering. The added 
cloud cover will drop highs into the upper 80s to lower 90s. Lows 
will be in the lower half of the 70s.

&&

.LONG TERM...
(Friday through Monday)
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Deterministic and ensemble guidance suggests the shortwave may
pinch off from the main trough and meander over the northern Gulf
this weekend, which will keep rain chances up a bit through the
weekend. However, guidance does differ on how much moisture
remains in the area as some northeasterly flow tries to become
re-established over the area. Regardless, the best rain chances
will generally remain across the southern and eastern parts of the
forecast area. Highs will be in the upper 80s in the east to the
mid 90s in the west. Lows will be in the low to mid 70s.

Next week, ridging will build across much of the southern US,
which will lead to a reduction in rain chances and an increase in
temperatures. Highs will return to the mid to upper 90s with lows
in the mid 70s. There will still be just enough dry air that our
heat index values will still remain around 100-105.

&&

.AVIATION...
(18Z TAFS)
Issued at 121 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

VFR conditions are expected over the next 24 hours. Some patchy
fog is possible near VLD around daybreak, but confidence is too
low to make any categorical changes. Winds will veer from out of
the NW this afternoon to out of the NE on Wednesday.

&&

.MARINE...
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Generally light and variable winds are expected over the next 24
to 36 hours before becoming more predominantly easterly late in
the week into the weekend. With this pattern, some nocturnal
easterly surges are possible, which may result in bouts of cautionary
conditions during the overnight hours. Seas will be around 1 to 3
feet. Chances for showers and thunderstorms will also increase
through the period.

&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Generally east to northeast transport winds will prevail Wednesday
through Friday with good to excellent dispersions across the area
each day. Min RH values will be in the mid-30s to mid-40s
Wednesday, increasing each day. Rain chances will also increase
each day, generally over southern and eastern parts of the area.
Overall, fire weather concerns remain low.

&&

.HYDROLOGY...
Issued at 221 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Areal flooding continues across southeastern Madison County as the
flood waters continue to shift generally eastward toward the
Suwannee River. Additional rainfall could exacerbate issues going
forward.

The lower Suwannee remains in minor flood, but all points are now
falling. This will continue to be a slow fall over the next 5-7
days. Additional rainfall over the next 7 days will not cause any
additional river flooding.

Flash flooding is not a significant concern either over the next 7
days. But, locally heavy rainfall cannot be ruled out in any
slow-moving storms.

&&

.SPOTTER INFORMATION STATEMENT...

Spotter activation is not requested. However, spotters are always 
encouraged to safely report significant weather conditions when they 
occur by calling the office or tweeting us @NWSTallahassee.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
Tallahassee   94  70  94  72 /   0   0  20  20 
Panama City   93  73  93  74 /   0   0  10  30 
Dothan        93  70  94  71 /   0   0  10  20 
Albany        94  71  92  71 /   0   0  20  20 
Valdosta      94  71  92  72 /   0   0  30  20 
Cross City    94  72  92  72 /  20   0  30  20 
Apalachicola  93  75  91  76 /   0   0  10  30 

&&

.TAE WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
FL...High Rip Current Risk until 8 PM EDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening for 
     FLZ114.

GA...None.
AL...None.
GM...None.
&&

$$
